References Created by Adding Items to Views

The addition of a new folder or item to a parent or child view can result in one or two references, depending upon the relationship between the two views.

If the child view is a branching, floating view, a reference is created in each view when a new folder or item is added to the parent. If the child view is a branching, floating view created with the Branch none option, a reference is created in each view when a new folder or item is added to the child.

Floating Downwards

When a view has a branching floating child view (created either with Branch none or Branch all) and the child view floats, any folder or item added to the parent view becomes visible in both views. The history of the folder or item indicates the view in which the object was created, and the reference hierarchy identifies the parent view as the parent reference.

Floating Upwards

When a view has a branching, floating child view created with the Branch none option, any folder or item added to the child view becomes visible in both views. This is not true of branching, floating child views created using the Branch all option.

The history of the folder or item indicates the view in which the object was created, but the reference hierarchy always displays a reference that identifies the parent view as the parent reference.

Floating Upwards and Downwards

If the view hierarchy is deep (the root view has grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and so on), the use of branching, floating views can cause a great deal of confusion. For example, suppose you add a file to a grandchild of the root view. Further suppose that the grandchild view was created using the Branch none option and that its parent (a child of the root view) was also created using the Branch none option. If you add a file, it can float up to the parent and grandparent of the current view, then float back down to the current view. The result is:

  • One reference to the file in the current view.

  • One reference to the file in the current view’s parent.

  • One reference to the file in the root view.

More references are created if the current view has floating children, grandchildren, and so on. Still more are created if the root view or parent view has other floating children besides the ones mentioned above.
